title: Tooltips using ggplotly
description:
In this post I highlight how to format tooltips from the ggplotly interface
to plotly from R
contents:
You can incorporate and format tooltips in the ggplotly interface. The ggplotly function has a tooltip option that can be inhabited by aesthetics in the ggplot code. By default it shows all the aesthetics specified in the ggplot code. In the following plot, all of the aesthetics (bill_length_mm, body_mass_g and species) are displayed in the tooltips. pacman::p_load(plotly, ggplot2, palmerpenguins) plt <- ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g))+ geom_point(aes(color = species)) + labs(x = 'Bill length (mm)', y = 'Body mass (g)', title = 'Penguins') ggplotly(plt) {"x":{"data":[{"x":[39.1,39.5,40.3,null,36.7,39.3,38.9,39.2,34.1,42,37.8,37.8,41.1,38.6,34.6,36.6,38.7,42.5,34.4,46,37.8,37.7,35.9,38.2,38.8,35.3,40.6,40.5,37.9,40.5,39.5,37.2,39.5,40.9,36.4,39.2,38.8,42.2,37.6,39.8,36.5,40.8,36,44.1,37,39.6,41.1,37.5,36,42.3,39.6,40.1,35,42,34.5,41.4,39,40.6,36.5,37.6,35.7,41.3,37.6,41.1,36.4,41.6,35.5,41.1,35.9,41.8,33.5,39.7,39.6,45.8,35.5,42.8,40.9,37.2,36.2,42.1,34.6,42.9,36.7,35.1,37.3,41.3,36.3,36.9,38.3,38.9,35.7,41.1,34,39.6,36.2,40.8,38.1,40.3,33.1,43.2,35,41,37.7,37.8,37.9,39.7,38.6,38.2,38.1,43.2,38.1,45.6,39.7,42.2,39.6,42.7,38.6,37.3,35.7,41.1,36.2,37.7,40.2,41.4,35.2,40.6,38.8,41.5,39,44.1,38.5,43.1,36.8,37.5,38.1,41.1,35.6,40.2,37,39.7,40.2,40.6,32.1,40.7,37.3,39,39.2,36.6,36,37.8,36,41.5],"y":[3750,3800,3250,null,3450,3650,3625,4675,3475,4250,3300,3700,3200,3800,4400,3700,3450,4500,3325,4200,3400,3600,3800,3950,3800,3800,3550,3200,3150,3950,3250,3900,3300,3900,3325,4150,3950,3550,3300,4650,3150,3900,3100,4400,3000,4600,3425,2975,3450,4150,3500,4300,3450,4050,2900,3700,3550,3800,2850,3750,3150,4400,3600,4050,2850,3950,3350,4100,3050,4450,3600,3900,3550,4150,3700,4250,3700,3900,3550,4000,3200,4700,3800,4200,3350,3550,3800,3500,3950,3600,3550,4300,3400,4450,3300,4300,3700,4350,2900,4100,3725,4725,3075,4250,2925,3550,3750,3900,3175,4775,3825,4600,3200,4275,3900,4075,2900,3775,3350,3325,3150,3500,3450,3875,3050,4000,3275,4300,3050,4000,3325,3500,3500,4475,3425,3900,3175,3975,3400,4250,3400,3475,3050,3725,3000,3650,4250,3475,3450,3750,3700,4000],"text":["bill_length_mm: 39.1

title: Flattening lists
description:
In this post, I explore various ways of flattening hierarchical lists in 
Python, contrasting with the built-in `unlist` function in R
contents:
Contents
Introducing the problem
First attempt
Doing this in Python
Finding a resource
The common method
Functional programming and reduce
Using pandas
Using itertools


Introducing the problem
Today, we will focus on the results of splitting text fields by a delimiter in R and Python. This will typically result in a list of lists. However, that would not do for my purpose.
The situation I was facing was to parse a text field containing one or more comma-separated disease names that were afflicting each patient in a study, and I wanted to make a frequency distribution of all the diseases among patients in the study, knowing that each disease would only appear at most once per patient. So I had to flatten the list of lists I would get by parsing the text field, so that I could then send it to a tabulation function like table in R or numpy.unique(..., return_counts=True) in Python.
First attempt
Let’s start with a text array containing the data in question.This data is an excerpt from a dataset provided for the PKDD ’99 Discovery Challenge


dat = readr::read_csv('dat.csv')
head(dat)


# A tibble: 6 × 1
  Diagnosis   
  <chr>       
1 RA susp.    
2 PSS         
3 SLE         
4 MCTD        
5 RA, SLE susp
6 SLE, MCTD   

There are comma-separated diseases here. We’ll ignore the obvious need to clean the text field of extraneous spaces for now. Let’s try separating out the different diseases.


stringr::str_split(dat$Diagnosis, ",")[1:5]


[[1]]
[1] "RA susp."

[[2]]
[1] "PSS"

[[3]]
[1] "SLE"

[[4]]
[1] "MCTD"

[[5]]
[1] "RA"        " SLE susp"

We see that this is a list of vectors (so we can nominally consider it a list of lists), some of length 1 and some with length more than 1. In order to tabulate the data, all we need is the unlist function.


table(unlist(stringr::str_split(dat$Diagnosis, ",")))



                     AIHA                  AORTITIS 
                        1                         1 
                     MCTD                        RA 
                        2                         1 
                  RA susp                       SJS 
                        1                        11 
                 SLE susp                   TA susp 
                        1                         1 
                 AORTITIS                    BEHCET 
                        1                         7 
          BEHCET (òsæSî^)          BEHCET (vasculo) 
                        1                         1 
              BEHCET susp                 Hyper CPK 
                        1                         1 
                     MCTD                       MRA 
                        5                         1 
                       PM                     PM/DM 
                        3                         3 
          PN (vasculitis)                       PSS 
                        1                         6 
                 PSS susp                PSS(CREST) 
                        1                         1 
                       RA                   RA susp 
                       12                         2 
                 RA susp.      Raynaud's phenomenon 
                        1                         1 
relapsingü@polychondritis           seronegative RA 
                        1                         1 
                      SJS                  SJS susp 
                       13                         4 
                      SLE                     Sweet 
                       30                         1 
    urticarial vasculitis                vasculitis 
                        1                         1 

Voila!!!
Doing this in Python
It turns out, doing a similar operation would also get you a list of lists in Python

import pandas as pd
dat = pd.read_csv('dat.csv')
d = dat.Diagnosis.str.split(",")
d[:5]
0         [RA susp.]
1              [PSS]
2              [SLE]
3             [MCTD]
4    [RA,  SLE susp]
Name: Diagnosis, dtype: object

It turns out, we don’t have an unlist function in Python!!
Finding a resource
Google being the all-encompassing deity of knowledge, I turned there and found this post describing 25 ways to flatten a list (and obviously a Simon and Garfunkel fan). There are a couple of one-liners in that post that I’ll highlight here.
The common method
Searches for this problem most commonly provide the following solution, either as a for-loop or a list comprehension

flatten_list = []
for sublist in d:
    for item in sublist:
        flatten_list.append(item)
flatten_list[:8]
['RA susp.', 'PSS', 'SLE', 'MCTD', 'RA', ' SLE susp', 'SLE', ' MCTD']

Functional programming and reduce

from functools import reduce
reduce(list.__add__, d)[:8]
['RA susp.', 'PSS', 'SLE', 'MCTD', 'RA', ' SLE susp', 'SLE', ' MCTD']

Functional programming provides functions that act on functions. Here, the reduce function applies the list.__add__ function recursively to successive elements of d, noting that adding two lists serves to concatenate them in Python.
A variant on this theme that works is

sum(d, [])[:8]
['RA susp.', 'PSS', 'SLE', 'MCTD', 'RA', ' SLE susp', 'SLE', ' MCTD']

since the sum function applies addition recursively from a starting value, which is the second argument. Here the addition operation is overloaded for lists to concatenate lists.
Using pandas
pandas does have a flatten function hidden in its depths

from pandas.core.common import flatten
list(flatten(d))[:8]
['RA susp.', 'PSS', 'SLE', 'MCTD', 'RA', ' SLE susp', 'SLE', ' MCTD']

Using itertools

import itertools
list(itertools.chain(*d))[:8]
['RA susp.', 'PSS', 'SLE', 'MCTD', 'RA', ' SLE susp', 'SLE', ' MCTD']

title: Frequency counts from lists
description: In this post I look at better ways of obtaining frequency distributions from a Python list, using methods **other than pandas**
contents:
Contents
Introducing the problem
Better ways
Using collections
Using numpy
Timings


Introducing the problem
How to you compute a frequency table from a list in Python? We’ll use a list named dat which is created by sampling the first 5 letters.

import string
import random

dat = random.choices(string.ascii_lowercase[:5], k = 100)

One way, that I use all the time, is

import pandas as pd
pd.Series(dat).value_counts()
b    26
e    22
c    20
a    18
d    14
dtype: int64

But can you do this without pandas? Turns out, you can
Better ways
Using collections

import collections
pd.Series(collections.Counter(dat))
d    14
b    26
c    20
a    18
e    22
dtype: int64

This creates a Series out of the output of Counter, which is a dict-like object.
Using numpy

import numpy as np
ans = np.unique(dat, return_counts=True)

This returns a tuple, which can be converted several ways, per this StackOverflow answer

pd.DataFrame(np.column_stack(ans), columns = ['item','count'])
  item count
0    a    18
1    b    26
2    c    20
3    d    14
4    e    22
pd.DataFrame(np.vstack(ans).T, columns = ['item','count'])
  item count
0    a    18
1    b    26
2    c    20
3    d    14
4    e    22
pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(ans), columns = ['item','count'])
  item count
0    a    18
1    b    26
2    c    20
3    d    14
4    e    22

Timings
Let’s look at timings for each of these methods.

import timeit
mysetup = """
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import collections, random, string
dat = random.choices(string.ascii_lowercase[:5], k=1000)
dat1 = pd.Series(dat)
"""


timeit.timeit('pd.Series(dat).value_counts()', setup=mysetup, number=1000)/1000
0.00046380726499955924
timeit.timeit('pd.Series(collections.Counter(dat))', setup=mysetup, number=1000)/1000
0.000220889652000551
timeit.timeit('pd.DataFrame(np.column_stack(np.unique(dat, return_counts=True)))', setup=mysetup, number=1000)/1000
0.00025998155500019495
timeit.timeit('pd.DataFrame(np.vstack(np.unique(dat, return_counts=True)).T)', setup=mysetup, number=1000)/1000
0.0002631664059990726
timeit.timeit('pd.DataFrame(np.transpose(np.unique(dat, return_counts=True)))', setup=mysetup, number=1000)/1000
0.0002664510020003945

So we can see that my usual strategy is half as efficient as the other strategies described in this post !!
What about if we start with a pandas Series anyway, and forgo the casting into a pandas structure?

timeit.timeit("dat1.value_counts()", setup=mysetup, number=1000)/1000
0.0003267870910003694
timeit.timeit("collections.Counter(dat1)", setup=mysetup, number=1000)/1000
9.801131499989425e-05

Even here, the pandas method is at quite the disadvantage.
